title: theresa may should go home
story: They did so by a huge margin. Sadly, a year or so later they also voted to keep the appalling Anna Soubry as their local MP. Let’s hope they never make that mistake again.For the last year this bilious, jabbering woman has done everything she possibly can to thwart the will of her electors.She is a staunch Remainer and is seemingly prepared to bring down the Government to get her way. Her actions suggest she couldn’t give a monkey’s about what the people in her constituency think.Two nights ago she was one of 12 Conservative rebels who voted against the Government. She wanted Britain to remain part of a customs union with the EU. That would mean — effectively — no real Brexit. And if they had won, it would have been catastrophe for the Government. And in my opinion, the country.The reason they didn’t lose is solely down to a bunch of courageous Labour MPs, including the excellent Frank Field, who voted with the Government. Soubry isn’t alone, of course. The people of Loughborough, Leics, also voted by a large margin to leave the EU.But they are represented in the House of Commons by Nicky Morgan, who appears not to give a toss what they think. She also voted for a customs union. Nicky is famous among many for being the second worst Education Secretary this country has ever had. She’s pipped to the post for that particular prize by Justine Greening.Being useless in their Cabinet posts isn’t the only thing that unites these two women. Greening is also opposed to Brexit and she has even called for a second referendum. Because she didn’t like the result of the first one.The people of Beaconsfield, Bucks, voted to leave the EU. But their MP, the grim Dominic Grieve, who resembles a funeral director from about 1923, appears not to care less. He has said he’s prepared to “collapse” the Government if he does not get his way.Sarah Wollaston is another one. Another embittered MP. Her constituency, Totnes in Devon, voted to leave by a sizeable margin.Because while it is true that the majority of Labour MPs are also opposed to Brexit, they have been nothing like as dangerous as the Tory rebels.We are in a mess. The Prime Minister staggers from crisis to crisis, striking meaningless deals whenever she can to stave off defeat for a few more days.She surely cannot last much longer. A Remainer herself, of course, I think she should be persuaded to call it a day. Go home, put her feet up. And let her party elect a leader who will take no more c**p from Brussels.And no more c**p from the likes of Soubry and Greening, either.THE top scientist Richard Dawkins – Britain’s most famous atheist – has got himself into trouble.He has said that he prefers to hear the sound of cathedral bells to the muezzin wail calling Muslims to prayer.  Saying something as inoffensive as that is enough to get you into hot water these days.Dawkins has been called a bigot as a consequence. I have to say I disagree with him. I love the sound of cathedral bells, sure.But I also enjoying hearing the Muslim call to prayer – when I’ve been on my travels in Morocco or Malaysia. But, over here, it’s cathedral bells for me every time.Here’s a tip, then.Take them to an expensive shoe shop and make them look at the display through the window.And remember the noise they make.KATIE PRICE is on holiday in Thailand and of course she’s got her baps out.  This might be a problem for Katie, pictured with boyfriend Kris Boyson.Topless sunbathing is against the law over there. This is because tourists enjoy looking at the scenic islands. Without having their view obliterated by a pair of breasts the size of Koh Samui.So watch yourself, Katie. And as a break from lying on the beach, how do you fancy a spot of caving?YOU’VE got to love the toffs, haven’t you?  Most of them are absolutely crazy after years of inbreeding.Take the brilliant Lizzie Purbrick who described herself as “a very well-bred toff”.  She went round to her married lover’s home after he’d cheated on her with a third woman.No messing with Lizzie. She took with her eight litres of pig’s blood which she sprayed across his flat. She daubed the words “slut” and “whore” and “big d**k lord” on his walls and sprayed a giant penis on the floor.  She said: “So many people have said I should write my life story, but I’m so bonkers I can’t remember it.”The judge said – in one of the great under-statements of the decade – that she had “real concerns about the defendant’s ability to make rational decisions”.No s**t, Sherlock.It started out a few years back with just a couple of stalls. Now the entire town centre is closed off and thousands turn up to pig themselves on cuisine from scores of nationalities.I got so stuffed last year I needed to be helped home. And not a chicken parmo – the supposed Teesside dish of choice – in sight.IT’S not often that the Labour peer Dame Margaret Hodge says something worth repeating. But in telling her party leader Jeremy Corbyn that he was a “f***ing anti-Semite and a racist” I think she kinda hit the nail on the head.Meanwhile, the decent, moderate Labour MP John Woodcock has resigned the party whip and become an independent.Long-time party members – like I was, until last year – know that Labour is currently led by a hard-left anti-Jewish rabble of thickoes.I hope the voters twig this sooner or later.AND now it’s time for Hypocrites of the Week. A special award for Pimlico Plumbers of London.They’ve put up a giant banner outside their premises about Brexit, saying: “Nobody voted to be poorer!”Pimlico Plumbers has just lost a landmark case brought by one of its employees. He, like almost all of their staff, was kept on a contract which allowed the firm to pay him less than the proper rate.They were done under a UK Supreme Court decision, using laws designed to stop unscrupulous firms exploiting cheap labour.I wonder what it is about the EU that Pimlico Plumbers likes so much? Can you take a guess?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: sun says irish pm leo varadkar
story: It has exposed beyond doubt both his crass naivety and the cynical deceit of the EU masters he cravenly obeys.Imagine the cataclysmic self-harm of Ireland preventing planes from its biggest trading partner flying over it. And the impossibility of its own airlines avoiding UK airspace. It won’t happen.Varadkar must believe that these grenades he brainlessly lobs into the Brexit negotiations help Brussels. He is not bright enough to realise how absurd and unstatesmanlike he looks.But he let something else very revealing slip too.Varadkar reportedly said that EU leaders have assured him no hard border or customs checks will ever be needed between Ireland and Northern Ireland.That’s under ANY scenario, including a No Deal.Since we will never build a hard border either, why is “avoiding” one still being discussed, let alone a huge sticking point?Answer: It is a ruse, confected by a Brussels desperate to keep us in its grip.Eurocrats yesterday tore apart Theresa May’s Chequers offer. Yes, the same offer already so over-generous it almost collapsed her Government.The Sun has never been more gloomy about the chance of a deal. There is nothing more Mrs May can compromise on.But Brussels is run by deluded bullies who apparently think they cannot lose.Martin Selmayr, the German who is effectively in charge, dislikes Britain and insists any deal must be punitive.The EU, while apparently negotiating with us, is also advising its members how to lure away our job-creating firms.Parliament, and its Remainers, must not be cowed. They must back Britain over Brussels. No Deal wasn’t our choice. But the EU is pushing us into it and telling its members to be prepared.Within eight months we must be fully ready too, economically and politically.THE huge surge in serious crime shames the supposed party of law and order.It is no coincidence murders, rapes, robberies and knife attacks are soaring with police numbers at a 36-year low.For years the Tories considered their necessary cuts to budgets safe enough. The evidence against is now irrefutable.But more cash is not the only answer.Many forces are appallingly led, obsessed with their image, with social media virtue-signalling and investigations driven by political correctness, all while ignoring the basics of keeping the public and their property safe.Home Secretary Sajid Javid must secure more money and reverse this horrific trend.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: diana would have known how to fix the meghan and thomas markle debacle
story: So many people have ­commented on the likeness between the late Princess Diana and Charlotte, the granddaughter she sadly never met.Diana often spoke of her desire for a daughter and she would have doted on Princess Charlotte.I can imagine proud Granny taking her to Disneyland and buying Princess outfits. She would have let Charlotte run riot in her bedroom, trying on all her designer clothes and shoes and raiding her make-up bag.It’s so tragic that all of these happy times were not to be. When William saw all of his children come into the world, most especially baby Charlotte, he must have felt the loss of his mother even more keenly.Diana would have been there with her arms full of presents, and not just for the babies. There would have been thoughtful gifts for Kate and lots of hugs and happy tears.You can well picture her ­giving newlywed Harry a cheeky nudge and telling him to “get on with it” so she could have more grandchildren to spoil.I also think that if Diana had still been alive this sad situation between Meghan Markle and her dad would never have been allowed to turn so toxic.Diana would have seen this potential problem looming even before the engagement was announced and nipped it firmly in the bud.She would have insisted and ensured he was invited to the UK and would have dispensed shrewd and invaluable advice on how to deal with all of the hoopla surrounding the wedding. Diana learned the hard way how to deal with the media and palace officials. She was misquoted, manipulated and misunderstood during her time as a royal wife and knew all the pitfalls and how to avoid them.Skittish Meghan would have been soothed and calmed and all of the bad feeling among the Markle family would have surely evaporated.Diana would have advised Meghan’s dad on his wedding suit, helped him with his speech and rehearsed him walking down the aisle.She would have put this rather shy and ordinary man completely at ease.Rather than watching his daughter getting married on TV while cowering in a cheap bed and breakfast in the US, he would have been an integral part of the happiest day of her life.Instead, we have a constant stream of ill-advised interviews given by Thomas where he appears to have been ignored and abandoned and, whether it’s fair or not, Meghan seems increasingly cold-hearted.Photos yesterday of. him celebrating his 74th birthday alone with just a fast food takeaway for company don’t exactly help, whether they were staged again or not.A present, phone call or card from Meghan would have gone a long way to build bridges.It’s all turning a tawdry soap opera meaning commentators such as Sharon Osbourne will keep the pot boiling.Just this week she inferred Thomas has a drink problem and should get clean, ensuring more lurid headlines and bad feeling as he furiously has to deny all of the allegations.No one is coming out of this well and never has Princess Diana been more missed.Harry needs her wise counsel and William knows what an important part she could have played in the lives of his ­children.I know her sons will never really get over her death, but I do hope when William looks into his daughter’s beautiful eyes he is heartened to see a reflection of his mum rather than finding it ­unbearably sad.THE way BBC News treated Cliff Richard was utterly shameful and I’m not in the least surprised it lost its court case.The poor man went through years of hell and became a virtual recluse – and his physical and mental health was profoundly affected.At a time when he should have been enjoying the rewards of a lifetime’s graft, he was enduring sleepless nights and often crying in anguish on the kitchen floor.Many in the media have expressed fear and disquiet that any sort of Cliff’s Law will mean restrictions on newspapers, radio and TV, and this is indeed troubling.But the blame should be pointed firmly at those who thought it was a good idea to send a helicopter to film and report an OTT police raid on an innocent man.Seeing Cliff outside the courtroom this week looking extremely fragile and on the verge of tears was heartbreaking.Clearly the sunny, friendly, optimistic Peter Pan of Pop has gone for good and in his place is a haggard, careworn, wary victim.Before the court case, Cliff told me he doesn’t have photos taken with fans and their children any more.It was painful to see the hurt and mistrust in his eyes.He then revealed this week that his VIP status meant he was allowed to use the secret Wimbledon tunnel under Centre Court and Court No1 to bounce quickly between both venues and view as much tennis as possible.Cliff doesn’t do that any more, and never will, because the tunnel goes past the ball boys’ changing area and he doesn’t want to put himself in a situation where he could potentially be accused of something unspeakable.I really hope that when enough time has passed he can get some of that old “glass half full” spirit back, but he will never be the person he was.And no one else should have to go through such a hideous ordeal when they have done nothing wrong.IF you don’t want to watch a movie that will make you laugh, cry and come out singing Abba songs, we can’t be friends.I thoroughly enjoyed Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again – a rare example of a sequel that is better than the original.The starry cast includes Meryl Streep, Julie Walters, PIerce Brosnan, Andy Garcia and Colin Firth. But the cherry on the icing on the cheesecake is the legend that is Cher.I was lucky enough to host the world premiere this week in London and had the chance to talk to the cast, who were effusive in their praise of Her Cherness.It was surprising to hear she STILL gets nervous before going on set and she was genuinely bewildered by all the love in the air for her.I thought one elderly gay gentleman was going to explode with happiness when Cher blew him a kiss.It was so endearing – and there is nothing more deliciously camp than Cher stepping out of a helicopter in a blonde wig and sequins before going on to sing Super Trouper. She’s a class act and a throughly lovely woman.WATCHING politicians squabble like ferrets in a sack soon loses its novelty value – and our eyes are now glazing over whenever the dreaded subject of Brexit rears its ugly head.But we should never forget that when we woke up the day after the referendum – to discover a majority had voted to leave the EU – there was NO actual plan.Bupkis. Nada. Zilch. Diddly-squat.There wasn’t even a “to do” list.Instead, all the rats deserted the sinking ship, claiming the dog had eaten their homework or a big boy did it and ran away – leaving the (female) PM to tidy up their reeking mess. Funny that.No matter which way you voted, surely we can all agree on one thing.There was little or no thought put into how to actually implement such a seismic change. Not even a few notes on the back of a fag packet.Now, two years down the line, the whole big, fat mess is farcical and beyond parody.As a nation, we are a laughing stock.Shame on all those careerists and fence-sitters for their arrogance, stupidity and downright mendacity in not having even a half-arsed plan in place.A parcel of rogues, right enough.IF you fancy a right good laugh at some silly, bonkers, hilarious fun and games, tune in to BBC1 today at 5.05pm for another helping of Wedding Day Winners with myself and Rob Beckett.One couple will actually get married at the end of the show and it’s all very lighthearted and joyful.DID Burberry REALLY need to make a bonfire of its overpriced designer swag and burn an eye-watering £28million worth of clothing and cosmetics?In line with other designer labels, the fashion house claims the move was to stop counterfeiters getting their hands on garments and using them to produce fakes.But surely that just doesn’t add up.If criminals want to reproduce any designer clothes or handbags, they can go into any shop and purchase something – or, even simpler, just order it online.Could Burberry not instead have the mother of all sales in aid of Help for Heroes, or for the homeless charity Centrepoint, or any number of deserving causes here and in the Third World?That £28million would have gone a hell of a long way to help those in need.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady prime minister legacy
story: Because . . . ’twas ever thus — right? Politics is a man’s world and, to many, women still feel like token visitors.Even when Tony Blair famously had 101 “babes” in his 1997 intake of MPs, only four of his Cabinet appointments were female.Here we are, 20 years later, and yes, we have a female Prime Minister but there is still a prevailing view that the Cabinet, in particular, belongs to men.Clearly there’s something profoundly wrong with that equation.Given that this country is made up, more or less equally, of men and women, things would undoubtedly be fairer, not to mention calmer, if more women were on board.So the big question is, why aren’t there?Things are better than they were. Since the 2017 election there are 208 women in the Commons, up from 191 in 2015.But there are still not enough and you don’t have to look far for reasons why that might be.Most women are put off by the environment and the culture and wonder why on earth they would want to put themselves within a country mile of either.Take Prime Minister’s Question Time, which appears to be a bunch of overgrown public school boys booing, jeering and jostling with each other in their bid to establish who is top dog.What woman in her right mind would choose to enter that fray?Then there are the practicalities. This week, Lib Dem MP Jo Swinson was “cheated” in a crunch Brexit vote by the breaking of her pairing pact.This is an arrangement where one MP agrees not to vote to cancel out the fact that another MP on the opposite side is unable to vote — in this case Swinson was at home with her three-week-old baby.The problem was, her pairing partner reneged on the deal and voted.Then there are the hours, which can be difficult if you have a family. Any woman would need a very understanding partner and family to do the job.Also, any MP is opening themselves up to the line of fire and a lot of personal criticism — which multiplies for female MPs.Some have to deal with endless comments and speculation about their appearance, as well as threats of rape and death on a regular basis. Just this week a man was arrested over abusive Facebook posts aimed at various female MPs.If it’s true voters are biased against women, any female has to be ten times as talented, determined and tenacious to get the job in the first place.It’s no wonder women are put off entering politics.But if we want true equality then more women need to go into Westminster and the culture needs to change.That is why I support the campaign group Women To Win and will be taking part in an event called The Voice Of Women In Politics.The idea is to try to encourage more women into Parliament, outlining some of the changes that need to take place to raise the number of female candidates.Getting more women into politics is a no brainer.Women tend to work collaboratively to solve problems whereas — in my experience — men are more likely to lock horns, point fingers and try to shout the loudest. All too often men are interested in progressing to be a leader, whereas women are more focused on getting the job done.And when women DO find their voice in politics, it can be very powerful, and they often hae the balls to say things that men just wouldn’t.Look at Tory minister Anna Soubry, who this week suggested the PM should take control of her hardliner MPs and stop pandering to the likes of Jacob Rees-Mogg.I know she’s got a lot on her plate at the moment, but if I was Theresa May I would be spending a good proportion of my time and energy on making real changes to politics in order, specifically, to attract many more women.It could be one of the greatest legacies she could hope for.Thomas Markle is a concerned dad who just wants to be reconnected with his daughter.Meanwhile this HALF-sister has turned a constant shade of green and wants to get involved in any way she can.Is it any wonder she wasn’t invited to the wedding?MY heroine of the week is 21-year-old Emilia Holden a waitress in Georgia, US, who was at the end of a shift when a customer casually grabbed her bottom as he walked past.Her response? She followed him, grabbed him and body slammed him to the ground, then called the police – after which he spent two nights in a police cell.What a fantastic response. Good for her.But also, who are these men that think that they can just grab a woman’s behind just because they want to?But hearing about elaborate plans by Pixie Lott which include a total of 18 bridesmaids all wearing the same dress, left me feeling a bit stressed out.Apart from anything else, it will take them all an hour to travel up the aisle.JAMES GODDARD-WATTS, the businessman whose family founded the hardware firm Screwfix, is still locked in a multi-million pound divorce battle with his ex-wife, Julia.They reached an agreement eight years ago ­– following the end of a 13-year marriage – that Mrs Goddard-Watts should get a £3.25million house and a £4million lump sum.But she complained that Mr Goddard-Watts had not revealed the full extent of his wealth at the time of the settlement and court fights began.Critics say Julia is a leech, greedy and after his money.But when you consider the worth and value of building a home, looking after children and a family while supporting a spouse, that should be worth at least half of whatever the partner who didn’t do all of that has earned in the meantime.So why shouldn’t she take him back to court?The law states that assets are divided equally.So people who hide theirs from their spouse only have themselves to blame if said spouse feels forced to take them to court to get what’s fair.ELLE Macpherson’s diet regime is enough to make me reach for the pizza delivery menu.The model is up at 5am. She has warm water, lemon and cayenne pepper.She has no booze, almost no carbs, no meat and no dairy. She is such a follower of the alkaline diet – based on the theory you can change the pH of your body through food – that she checks the acidity of her urine.I’m sure the diet is good for her – but who wants to add years to your life if those years are going to be so, well, dull?“The only chance I have of being on TV again is if I were very ugly,” he said.“I think only old, ugly women can get on TV. Like Mary Beard.”David added that he would only be hired now: “If I had tombstone teeth and rather funny hair and made a lot of noise about that fact.”Oh dear.Where even to start? When you resort to attacking someone’s appearance, you are in trouble.It’s not Mary Beard that has held back his career. It’s David himself.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: ayesha hazarika clusterfudge pm dishcloth leadership
story: The Tories are so busy plotting against each other they have forgotten there is a country to run.They have become a circular firing squad. Or a crap remake of Fight Club — except they DO talk about Fight Club. All the time.Theresa May has the leadership skills of a damp dishcloth, no authority and no political vision.A strong leader needs a clear mission. You may not agree with it, but you know what they stand for.“Live each day like it’s your last,” is our Prime Minister’s political strategy, except she’s not dancing in the rain.She is waiting for the sharks to circle. And soon they will come for her.Buffoon-in-chief Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg — a man so old-fashioned he could have been dug up by Time Team — wait to pounce. And Brexit is a mess. Things are so bad, even Elon Musk is out of ideas. No one will be happy with where we end up.And because there is no party political or Brexit majority in the Commons, politics is stuck, trapped in what feels like a never-ending Brexistential crisis.Normally, I’m with “Brenda From Bristol” when it comes to more elections and referendums.But maybe a People’s Vote on the final deal or another election is the only way to unblock Brexit.Think of it like a political plunger — unpleasant, nasty but necessary.You’d think the Opposition would be gleefully capitalising on all this chaos. Think again. Instead of going after the Tories, Labour has decided to traumatise the Jewish community. Again.Labour has had a horrible problem with anti-Semitism, yet instead of healing the wound, it has poured vinegar on it by choosing not to adopt the full International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance code of conduct.These guys sound pretty authoritative and the code is good enough for government departments and the Crown Prosecution Service.Many Jewish groups and leaders, including the Chief Rabbi, are distraught, confused and angry. And you can see why.This shameful decision led to an angry clash outside the Commons chamber where Jewish MP Margaret Hodge confronted Jeremy Corbyn, allegedly calling him an anti-Semite and a racist.Hodge lost family in the Holocaust and fought off the BNP in her Barking and Dagenham constituency.Instead of acknowledging her pain and offering to sit down with her, Team Corbyn are taking disciplinary action against her.I bet they deal with her far quicker than they did with Ken Livingstone, who couldn’t stop banging on about Hitler.What dark times for Labour, which once had a proud tradition of fighting racism. They must sort it out.Then we have the Lib Dems, who have proved useless. They have one policy — stop Brexit.Yet leader Vince Cable and ex-leader Tim Farron missed crucial votes on Monday. Talk about Dem and Dumber.To top it all off, the DUP’s Ian Paisley Jnr has been suspended for 30 days — which hasn’t happened since 1949 — for failing to declare lavish holidays to that well-known Northern Irish stakeholder, Sri Lanka.And to think Theresa May planned to give MPs an extra five days off as a reward for all their hard work.The country has had enough of these fools’ infighting, incompetence and filling their boots. Especially when we face so many big problems, from NHS funding to housing.Parliament’s end-of-term report is a big, fat fail. British politics should be taken into special measures.THE premiere of Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again was sun-kissed, frothy fun –  and no one mentioned the ­Customs Union. Bliss.The stars were out in full, including Cher. She is magnificent, but it is a little odd that at 72 she has fewer wrinkles than any other cast member, including 29-year-old Lily James. And the baby.She told Lorraine Kelly it was down to not drinking, smoking or doing drugs. Yeah, right.We women may be naive when it comes to the quest for eternal beauty, but we ain’t stupid.WHEN you hear of people getting up in the middle of the night and queuing, you think of the Boxing Day sales or the release of the latest Apple gadget.You don’t think of childcare.Yet more than 100 parents queued from 3am – armed with chairs, flasks and biscuits – trying to bag their child a coveted place in the breakfast club at a primary school in Cardiff.For many working parents, breakfast clubs are a lifeline.They can drop off the children in a safe environment where they can get a decent breakfast, then make it to work on time themselves.Though parents have the right to request flexible working hours, many fear the sack if they come in late.These spaces were limited and dished out on a first-come, first-served basis, which is why the parents took such drastic measures.This shows how desperate parents are for childcare that matches their working hours.The scrapping of Labour’s extended school programme and the first real-terms cuts to schools mean all these extras that were provided are no longer affordable.Childcare isn’t a luxury.It’s a necessity for millions of families and they are crying out for more breakfast and after-school clubs.JEFF BEZOS, the boss of Amazon, is a man clearly in his “Prime”.He’s now the richest man in modern history.Good for him.I’m all for celebrating entrepreneurs and hard work – but shouldn’t that apply to his poor workers toiling away in his warehouses?They would probably give Amazon working conditions zero stars.I wish our business leaders remembered some of their forefathers, who felt a moral and civic responsibility to look after their employees and took some pride in that.It makes business sense too. Happy workers are better workers.So after Bezos pops open the champagne, maybe he could spare a thought for his staff, who told an undercover reporter they pee in bottles because the loos are too far away and they are afraid of being accused of time-wasting.C’mon, Jeff – that’s really taking the p**s. ONE school in Liverpool had to apologise after kids as young as four were left in tears when they were denied an ice cream treat because they didn’t have a 97 per cent attendance record.How mean is that? What if they were ill? And surely it’s the parents’ fault.CARERS got another kick in the teeth this week when the Court of Appeal overturned a decision that those doing sleep-in shifts should earn at least the minimum wage.If the decision had gone through, it would have cost the UK care sector billions – so charities and local governments were relieved.But it shows what a raw deal carers get.Judges said only hours spent awake counted as work – but that is completely out of touch with the reality of what carers do.Many of the elderly and vulnerable people they look after need their help through the night, whether it’s a trip to the loo, to take medication or dealing with more serious situations such as seizures. Carers can’t exactly fall into a deep sleep. They have to be alert and listening in case they are needed.The rooms they sleep in may not be comfortable and they will be away from their own families.Many carers are paid so little that they live hand to mouth and barely get by.When I met a group in the West Midlands, they told me they couldn’t afford to put the heating on in winter and had to take their kids to the grandparents’ for tea once or twice a week just so they would be fed.Some were struggling so much they had to visit food banks.But they also loved their jobs and took great pride in looking after their clients as if they were family.They get paid a pittance, with some earning just £30 for a ten-hour shift.These low-paid workers – the majority of whom are women – are unsung heroes and deserve more.New Health Secretary Matt Hancock must make social care a priority and enforce minimum-wage law properly.It’s time we took better care of our carers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: england world cup heroes holidays
story: Several of the players who made it to the competitions semi-finals have shared snaps of their luxury getaways.Harry Maguire and Raheem Sterling have been spotted making the most of their free time in Ibiza.Harry Maguire, the 25 year-old defender, posted a picture of him with his fiancée, Fern Hawkins, and their friends on a yacht in Ibiza.Raheem Sterling, 23, was also on the party island.He was seen enjoying the sun on a family getaway with his fiancée Paige Milian and children, Melody Rose and Thiago.Other team members headed to equally sunny destinations.Dele Alli, who scored the second goal of the game for England as they knocked out Sweden with a win in the quarter-finals, was seen living the high life in LA.He was spotted on Thursday night partying at The Nice Guy bar in West Hollywood.Also there was Paul Pogba - celebrating Frances World Cup win.Manchester United ace, Jesse Lingard, has also been seen enjoying a California getaway.The 25 year-old, who scored his first ever World Cup goal in a 6-1 victory against Panama, has been documenting his travels with the hashtag #JLingzToTheWorld.Hes shared snaps of his pals and of him poolside.He was also spotted by paps enjoying himself at Avenue LA, an exclusive nightclub in Hollywood.Unlike his other teammates, Jordan Pickford, 24, stayed a little closer to home.The goalkeeper enjoyed the first day of The Open at Carnoustie in Scotland.The Everton player even took up a challenge from a Sky Sports presenter to show off his own golfing prowess.He nervously drove the ball 85 yards down the fairway.This put Pickford at the bottom of the leaderboard.This was expected given that every other competitor was a professional golfer.The celebratory holiday snaps come after England gaining fourth place in the World Cup.Despite not winning overal, fans celebrated a largely successful campaign that saw England achieve their best result since 1990.Harry Kane winning the prestigious Golden Boot, after finishing as the World Cups top scorer, also softened the blow of losing to Croatia in the semi-final for many England supporters.Just as Luka Modric winning the Golden Ball softened the blow for many Croatian fans following Frances overall victory in the competition.

title: chancellor philip hammond calls boris bogeyman
story: In an astonishing outburst, the Chancellor said there is more chance of striking a deal since Bojo quit the Cabinet.And he claimed the departure of Brexit Secretary David Davis would strengthen Britain’s hand in the next round of talks.Mr Hammond told colleagues there were “upsides and downsides” to the wave of resignations over the PMs Chequers Brexit blueprint.He said: “They know we are serious. We are pushing the envelope.”But when discussion turned to the loss of two Cabinet big guns, the usually gloomy Chancellor delivered a rare upbeat verdict.He declared: “The two main bogeymen have been taken off the board.”Last night his off-the-cuff remark was described as “arrogant” and “disdainful” by angry Brexiteers.They claimed it betrayed his staunch Remainer tendencies and determination to keep Britain shackled to the EU.A senior Brexiteer said last night: “With each day that passes, it is clear that this is more and more a Remain-run Brexit.“We have a Remain Prime Minister, a Remain Cabinet Office and most clearly of all a Remain Chancellor who is happy to undermine British interests and wave the white flag of surrender to Brussels as these comments prove once again.“It shows he is on the side of Brussels and not the 17.4million people who voted to leave the EU.”Former Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith added: “There is no room in the Conservative party for arrogant and disdainful remarks about colleagues.“Who’s to say that, for some, it may well be the Chancellor who turns out to be the bogeyman.”Grant Shapps, who called for an “orderly” change after the 2017 election shambles, urged MPs to close ranks and get EU talks done.Tory MP Andrea Jenkyns, who quit as a ministerial aide over the Chequers blueprint, added: “I have nothing but the highest admiration for my colleagues David Davis and Boris Johnson.“They both made a brave and principled stand in putting the country before their party or their careers.“As for the Chancellor, if I were him, I’d be worred about the reaction of 17.4million people who voted for Brexit and already feel betrayed. They won’t be going away.“Philip Hammond has become nothing more than a mouthpiece for the PM’s EU-loving Europe adviser Olly Robbins.”Mr Hammond’s outburst has put Theresa May’s attempts to restore Cabinet unity at risk.The Chancellor, who is no stranger to Cabinet bust-ups, has clashed with several colleagues over Brexit and the squeeze on spending.He was accused of likening Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson to Private Pike from TV comedy classic Dad’s Army.After a clash over lack of military funding, an ally of Mr Hammond said: “Williamson doesn’t know one end of a rifle from the other.“When he is with all these grizzled old forces types, he just sites there looking like Private Pike from Dad’s Army.”An ally said: “I’ve never heard Philip use the word bogeyman against any colleague. He is a great admirer of David Davis and would never talk in a disparaging way about him.“Perhaps he was saying that the EU saw these two people as bogeymen. I’m sure Philip never has.”A senior Cabinet source said Mr Hammond was expressing the harsh reality – in his trademark clumsy way.He said: “I agreed with Philip’s sentiments but not the language used.“I suspect he was trying to say it is important to have a Cabinet united behind the same plan and removing two outspoken critics is a positive step.“However, to call hem bogeymen is over the top and will only inflame the precarious peace between the Leave and Remain camps.”If that’s the case then surely we won’t be conceding any more to Brussels.The evidence on Friday — when the EU slapped down Theresa May’s Chequers offers — suggests otherwise.Hammond’s disparaging remark shows that Remainers are at the heart of Theresa May’s Government, running the show at the expense of Leave voices.This Government sees Brexit as a damage-limitation exercise rather than a golden opportunity for Britain to reinvent itself as a global and buccaneering free nation.How can we ever achieve Brexit in full if the Government itself is so institutionally Euro-phile? We need more Brexiteers at the heart of the project.Meanwhile, it is clear that the PM’s Chequers plan has not only failed to win over Brussels, but also her party. The grassroots are livid.It was as generous an offer as Mrs May could politically have tabled.Every time we are reasonable in our approach, the EU slaps us down. They are determined to punish us.We can’t just keep giving while the EU arrogantly takes. Enough is enough.It is clear Mrs May needs to change her approach to Brexit - and fast.The PM has repeatedly said: “No deal is better than a bad deal”.She must be true to her words — and properly start planning for such a scenario.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: peeping tom tourist attraction
story: Police also fear children using the 16ft-high attraction might get explicit views.Planners have given the go-ahead for the tower to be added to Peter Pan’s Adventure Golf in Brighton.But Neville Wren, who advises on crime prevention at Sussex Police, said it could turn into a voyeurs’ paradise.He said: “This facility is most likely to provide activities for various age groups from school-age children to adults.“From the raised platform positions it possibly provides views towards the naturist beach nearby.“This in turn may cause unexpected concerns from the parents of young children.”The section of naturist beach near the marina is signposted to warn ­passers-by what they might see.Writing on social media Philip Marlowe blasted the city council, writing: “So it’s alright for kids to see hundreds of nudists around Brighton on the Naked Bikers Day, even if they and their parents have no choice, but not to see a few on the beach. Talk about hypocrisy!”Brighton Nerly said: “Bearing in mind what can be seen elsewhere in society — even on a Women’s Institute calendar — just how corrupting would the ­distant view of a nudist be?”The proposed attraction has been described as like the Go Ape brand of treetop adventures, and would tower above the mini-golf course.It was approved for six years by Brighton and Hove City Council.There were five letters of objection, with people concerned about the impact on nearby houses. A further 22 letters of support described the attraction as brilliant for children and great for the economy.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kids as young as eight have been clocked speeding by cops
story: Two youngsters have been recorded as going above the speed limit over the past 18 months, according to shocking figures.Youths aged 14 or under were found to have breached rules on careless driving, speeding or dangerous driving on 55 occasions in total.Figures released by the DVLA, from court records, show more than 300 driving offences were commited by fifteen and sixteen year olds.Overall there were nearly 2,000 incidents of those aged under 17, the minimum age to hold a full car licence, being handed driving notices.If drivers have yet to reach driving age, a non-licence holder record is established to record motoring convictions.Rules also state that drivers who pick up six or more penalty points in the first two years after passing their first test will have their licences taken away.The RAC indicated fingerprint recognition could be used to start cars and vehicles to help stop the offences.Steve Gooding, director of the RAC Foundation, said: “Fingerprint recognition already protects our mobile phones, so how long until biometric security becomes common in cars and other vehicles so only those supposed to drive them actually do?”A spokesperson for the Sentencing Council said: “There are no sentencing guidelines specifically for young offenders convicted of driving offences.”They said judges would take an “individualistic approach and focus on the young person with a view to encouraging them to take responsibility for their actions and prevent re-offending”.They added: “A court may also consider a relevant adult sentencing guideline and as a rough guide for a 15-17 year old apply a sentence two-thirds to half the adult sentence.”GOT a story? title: ministry of defence thomas cooke jet2 holidays
story: Taxpayer funded planes are being used to take Thomas Cook and Jet2 passengers to Majorca, Tenerife and Florida in a controversial deal, according to the Mail on Sunday.The Airbus A330s are meant for refuelling bombers and taking Brit troops to war zones.But a big-money deal with aviation firm AirTanker allows commercial use of the jets, bringing in millions for the MoD.The Mail says it  tracked three such RAF planes flying Thomas Cook holidaymakers from Manchester to New York, Seattle, Boston and Orlando, and a Jet2 plane to Tenerife.It says the aircraft, nicknamed Voyager, have never been used in military operations.The MoD has also been slammed for shelling out £94 million on an overpriced aircraft hangar, and spending millions more on the same planes which cost the Australian air force less.A source close to Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson is quoted in the paper saying: Poor historic deals like this are squeezing the defence budget and leaving no room to manoeuvre.Voyager is one of the reasons we have to fight for more funds to avoid devastating cuts elsewhere.The deal with AirTanker was signed off in 2008, when Gordon Brown was Prime Minister.Armed Forces Minister John Spellar told th epaper the deal was putting troops on the ground at risk.He said: The bottom line is that bad deals like this cost lives.Voyager has left the MoD so short of cash that troops have gone without top-grade equipment.

title: tories thrash brexit blueprints
story: Up to 80 constituency chiefs gave the PM’s senior aides a piece of their mind when they were invited to 10 Downing Street to have the plan explained to them by chief of staff Gavin Barwell and party chairman Brandon Lewis.One said: “It was very tense throughout the presentation but once it was finished all hell broke loose.“There were cries of betrayal and snorts of derision. People were volubly angry.It was clear nobody likes this plan and nobody was falling for the spin.”The insider said only about five people had anything positive to say.He added: “It was very uncomfortable for the staff.Even the chairman of a remain-voting constituency didn’t have a good word to say about the plan. I think they got the message loud and clear.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: david davis brexit theresa may interview
story: The outgoing Brexit secretary told the Express that his wife convinced him to resign and he mulled over his decision for two days before taking the leap after Theresa May revealed her Chequers plan to him.He hit out at the Treasury for mumbo jumbo maths and said quitting the EU with a no deal would not be the end of the world.Asked if it was too late to save Brexit, Davis said: It’s not too late but we’re going to have to fight very hard from outside to influence the way the Government goes.Through September and October it’s going to be a very high intensity argument, I think.But he admitted that Autumn would be a crunch time, and if no agreement was in place we’re going to have to start again.David Davis announced his resignation minutes before midnight on July 8, 2018, with a devastating letter warning Mrs May her proposals would leave the UK in a weak negotiating position with Brussels.He revealed he holed up in his home in Yorkshire listening to Mozart while mulling over whether to quit.Davis told the paper: When I make a big decision I always put two days’ cooling off period in my own mind.The big things in my mind were: One: can I stand at the despatch box and say this? And tell the truth? And the answer’s no.He added: I talked it over with my wife and her advice was: Leave. Mind you, she’s had to put up with the workload and the absence.Davis says Theresa May would look at deals struck with other countries - Canada, South Korea, South Africa, Switzerland, New Zealand - and create a best-of dossier as a bargaining chip.And he slammed the Treasury for fear mongering, saying: You’ve got a Whitehall establishment which putting it mildly, is not an enthusiast for the project. And certainly at the Treasury, which believes all these nonsensical forecasts. Project Fear Mark III, I think it is now.The Treasury in total believes this stuff and I don’t. I simply think this is mathematical mumbo jumbo.He also denied wanting to replace May as PM adding: I’ve just given up my job, I don’t want another one.Davis tipped his Brexit sec successor, Dominic Raab to succeed in the role - calling him my boy.Discussing the notion of a no deal, he admitted the country is not yet prepared for that eventuality, but said it would not be the end of the world.Davis says if there was a second Brexit vote, the victory would be more emphatic - with Remainers becoming disheartened by the confusion and wishy-washy nature of the split.He said: I think they would. I think it would be about 60-40 .

title: girlfriend of brit schoolboy who planned school massacre describes how he carved his name into her back with knives
story: Thomas Wyllie, jailed this week for 12 years, left the 15-year-old with scarring and facing a lifetime of pain.The girl - who cannot be named for legal reasons - said Wyllie carried out the sick act in a filthy shack behind a Londis minimart.The  reports how Wyllie was plotting the devastating school massacre at the time.The girl said: He wanted to hurt me. Having your young lover saw and cut at you with a blade is both physically and mentally scarring.He physically abused and harmed me. Tore me down until I had nothing, so I’d have to go back to him.He made me believe his ideas were right. That everything was evil except him. That he was God.”Wyllie even imagined the aftermath, writing in his diary: “If this is found I have committed one of the worst atrocities in British history or I killed myself.”He and Bolland claimed they were seeking revenge for bullying.But twisted plot mastermind Wyllie hated authority figures and was obsessed with serial killers and blood-thirsty films.Bolland boasted of their plan in a text to a pupil saying: “You know we’re gonna do this school shooting . . . don’t take it as a joke.”The trial earlier heard the pair hero-worshipped Columbine shooters Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold who killed 13 people in 1999.The girl said: “He dressed like Eric all the time, he was proud, he admired him, he worshipped him.”The pair downloaded a bomb-making manual to make a device like the one that killed 22 people at the Ariana Grande concert in Manchester in May last year.They intended to torture and murder the parents of Wyllie’s girlfriend and steal her dad’s shotguns.After lying low at a hideout where they had stashed screws and flammable liquid to make a nail bomb, they would attack the school.Dressed in trench coats, the demented duo began opening fire on pupils outside the school before moving inside and spraying bullets at victims in the library.It later emerged Harris and Klebold placed two duffel bags each containing a 20-pound propane bomb set to explode in the cafeteria and waited outside.But when the bombs failed to go off, they started gunning down students - firing a total of 188 rounds of ammunition during the bloodbath.The pair murdered 12 students and one teacher and injured 21 others before they killed themselves after a shootout with police.But the massacre was tragically not a one off and children in America continue to be exposed to gun violence that is unparalleled anywhere in the Western world.More than 187,000 kids have been exposed to gun violence at school since Columbine.Wyllie and Bolland were found guilty of conspiracy to murder at Leeds crown court in May.Neither showed any emotion as judge Mrs Justice Cheema-Grubb said: “You were only 14 when you planned to murder teachers and pupils.”She locked up Wyllie for 12 years and Bolland for ten.

title: david beckhams broke nephew says hes been frozen out of the family while brooklyn and romeo live the high life
story: Freddie Every, 17, grew up playing with his cousins Romeo and Brooklyn but now lives in temporary housing with his hard-up dad.The footie-mad teen feels he was cast adrift when his dad Colin, 50, and Becks’ eldest sister Lynne split up after 11 years of marriage in 2010.Freddie is now on a bricklaying course while living with his dad in a one-bedroom council flat in Dagenham, East London, reports the Sunday Mirror.He is desperately trying to reach out to the Beckhams and is dying to be reunited with his extended family.Freddie told the newspaper: “I just want to be able to go for a meal and talk and catch up. I’m not asking for more than that. They are still my family and I’d like to see them again.“Growing up we saw them loads and I have so many happy memories of playing at their house, doing Easter egg hunts and playing on quad bikes.“Then suddenly it all stopped and I am on the outside looking in, only seeing them live their lives on Instagram or on the TV.”The teen has been reminiscing about the time he played with Becks and Cruz at Rowneybury House in Hertfordshire.He also remembers the time David bought him a McDonald’s Happy Meal when he was a kid.And despite growing up with Brooklyn, their lives could not be more different as Freddie has just £1.36 in his bank.Freddie’s first job was at Romford Market, where he worked on a noodle stall earning £200 a month.Brooklyn, however, recently took home £100,000 for a photo shoot he did for phone company Huawei.He is forced to ride a mountain bike because he can’t afford driving lessons while his famous cousin drives a £35,000 Land Rover.Freddie last saw Becks, 43, nine years at a Chinese restaurant in Harlow, Essex, and in 2012 he went for a meal at Pizza Express with his cousins and Victoria, 44.

title: water shortage 2018 ailing water company united utilities tells customers to water their garden with bath water amid heatwave
story: United Utilities, which supplies three million households in north-west England, said the lack of rain has dried up its reservoirs, leaving water levels drastically lower than usual for this time of year.The water company also loses more than 400 million litres of water every day from leaks, and has turned to sniffer dogs to detect pipe faults.In a statement posted on its website, the company said: We’ve taken the decision to introduce a hosepipe ban across most of the North West on the 5th August.The ban means customers will not be allowed to use either a hosepipe or sprinkler to water their gardens.They were also told not to fill up paddling pools, or face fines of up to £1,000, according to reports.Instead, customers were advised to water their gardens with bath water after using it to clean themselves.The statement added: Please use a watering can instead or, even better, reuse any water from the home such as water from washing up bowls or bath water.We know hosepipe bans can be inconvenient but by taking these steps now we can make sure we have enough water for more essential things like drinking, washing and cooking.The North West is the second region facing a hosepipe ban after Northern Ireland.Water in the region is stored in open reservoirs so when it stops raining they stop filling up.This year the UK has experienced its driest June since 1976, and the hot weather is likely to continue through the rest of July.But the dry weather is not the only reason for the water shortage. United Utilities has come under fire for wasting water during the heatwave.According to the BBC, the water company loses 25% of its supplies through leaking pipes, which amounts to 439.2 million litres a day.That is the equivalent of more than one and a half bath tubs of water for every property, every day.To combat the problem, UU has turned to Snipe, a 21-month-old cocker Spaniel, which has undergone weeks of special training to detect tiny amounts of chlorine found in tap water.Snipe will be used to find leakages in rural areas where they are hardest to detect.UU is responsible for a network of 42,000 kilometres of pipes. With a team of 140 personnel, using drones and sound detection, it fixes around 27,000 leaks a year.But critics say more needs to be done to stop the leaks and potentially end the water shortage crisis.

title: chief remoaner claims no deal would put britain in state of emergency but dominic raab says well thrive no matter what
story: The pro-EU Tory insisted that no-deal would spark a huge crisis in the country and we would run out of food and medicine.Mr Grieve, who has been in charge of leading other Remainers to water down Theresa Mays Brexit Bill in the Commons on numerous occasions, denied his comments were another attempt at Remains Project Fear today and insisted it would be absolutely catastrophic if talks broke down with Brussels.He told Skys Sophie Ridge on Sunday this morning: Its right to take emergency measures, but we will be in a state of emergency.And he even claimed basic services like flights abroad wouldnt be able to take place, and there would be trouble getting food into the country.It is so serious - I find it difficult to see that no deal is better than a deal on offer, the Beaconsfield MP said.Ministers have drawn up secret plans to stockpile processed foods in case of a no-deal Brexit, and have started putting in place contingency plans.Last week Mrs May and the EU told businesses to start stepping up their preparations for not securing a Brexit deal with the EU.Advice will be given out across the summer for how to start getting ready.But Brexit Secretary Dominic Grieve insisted that we will thrive when we come out of the EU - no matter what happens.He insisted that far-fetched, fanciful predictions of what would happen when we leave would not come true, and he was confident of securing an arrangement.Mr Raab said the UK was hiring extra border staff and pumping in money to departments to prepare.Speaking to the Andrew Marr Show he said: People need to know we are getting ready and Britain can thrive no matter what happens.And he was confident that we would be able to get a deal by October, with his fresh injection of energy, ambition and pragmatism.80 per cent of the withdrawal agreement is already sorted, he confirmed today. And he insisted the Government would do everything it needed to smooth over any bumps we may face in the coming months.We will act responsibly and set out the details of that through technical notices over the coming months, he added.If we have no deal, we will make sure we are prepared - we will have all the planning in place and the infrastructure to deal with that.But he said that Mr Barnier asking questions about the UKs plans for Brexit was a good positive sign and ministers were pleased to see it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: newborn baby left hot car tesco newton abbott devon car park
story: The disturbing footage sparked fury online after an eyewitness heard the baby crying in a supermarket car park.The car was spotted in the car park of Tesco in Newton Abbot on Thursday, when temperatures reached around 26 degrees.A man recording the cries is heard to say the baby is screaming its head off and that it was outrageous and out of order.According to a report on Devon Live supermarket staff issued an urgent shop broadcast when they were informed of the baby in the car by a member of the public.A Tesco spokesman said: A customer told one of our colleagues that a young child had been left on their own in a parked car at our Newton Abbot store.We put out a call in store for the vehicle’s driver, and they returned to their car.Commenting on the incident on social media, one person confirmed it was the grandfather who had left the baby in the car and the parents were now aware of it.Writing online, some said it was horrendous and  disgusting.Meanwhile, the British Red Cross issued a warning urging everyone to take care in the soaring temperatures last month.

title: divers swim 20 shaks cornwall coast
story: The 20-strong pack were snapped off the coast of Penzance, and were thought to have been attracted by the warm weather.Charles Hood, who runs Blue Sharks Cornwall, took the stunning picture while offering customers the “ultimate shark adventure in Cornish waters”.He told Cornwall Live: “There have always been blue sharks in Cornish waters but they’ve definitely increased in the past couple of years.We normally see ten when we go out, five on a poor day but around 20 on a good day.I would say there’s usually double the amount around that you see.”Charles runs shark-spotting trips from Penzance - and his jaunts have proved a hit with celebrities.He claims that BBC presenter Steve Backshall once took one his tours - which have been featured on The One Show and Countryfile.He added: The blues can appear within minutes or up to a couple hours but once around the RIB they will often stay for a few hours at a time.Encounters are best photographed either using a pole-cam or snorkelling.”

title: british teenager harpooned eye
story: Cops said Devon White, 14, was with his family on a boat and was loading the lethal razor sharp harpoon when it went off at more than 60mph and struck him in the left eye.The steel bolt went through his diving mask which was left shattered and embedded itself more than six inches into his head following the incident at the seaside resort of Sperlonga near Rome.His uncle and older brother were on the hired boat with two friends and they frantically raced back to the beach where lifeguards alerted paramedics.Devon, from Chelmsford, Essex, was given emergency first aid and stayed conscious throughout, speaking to paramedics and police who were amazed he was still alive.Because of the injury he was airlifted 100 miles to a specialist hospital in Rome where he underwent three hour surgery to remove the bolt and his parents were at his bedside.The bolt appeared to have missed vital organs and blood vessels although doctors said it was still too early to tell if he would make a full recovery and if he would lose his eye.Cops said the group had been firing the Cressi Sioux harpoon at rocks and the bolt had been damaged which meant it had not loaded properly and was the likely cause for it to fire.Officials also said that at 14 he was too young to have been handling the weapon and they were preparing a report fort the local prosecutor who would decide if charges should be brought against his uncle or older brother.Local carabinieri chief Salvatore Capasso told The Sun on Sunday: It’s a miracle this boy is still alive. I have never seen anything like it.The bolt was in his head and he was still alive and talking. I’m amazed he didn’t die.He must have a  angel or some other divine help because he is still alive.I’ve seen many things during my career but nothing as macabre as that. I can’t believe he was still able to talk to me.He was on the boat with his uncle, brother and two friends and they were shooting the harpoon at rocks.It appears the bolt was damaged and then when it was reloaded it didn’t lock properly and so when he stood up it went off and shot through his mask and into his head.The bolt was embedded in his head but appears to have missed his brain and other blood vessels.It went into a cavity behind his forehead.He is in hospital now and we are all hoping he pulls through.A file is being prepared for the local prosecutor as he was underage and shouldn’t have been handling the harpoon.As the uncle and brother are older and technically in charge it’s possible they could face action but that is for the prosecutor.A Foreign Office official said they were unaware of the incident.GOT a story? title: 7 truly alarming things been
story: News7 truly alarming things that have been said about Brexit this weekendParliament may be winding down for the summer, but the arguments over Brexit are as furious as ever&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter16:21, 22 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailParliament may be winding down for the summer, but the arguments over Brexit are as furious as ever. Since Michel Barnier responded to Theresa May’s Brexit White Paper with a very polite “non” on Friday, it’s been all out war in the Tory ranks. Between the outcry over Vote Leave cheating in the campaign, the claims of Mad Max style armageddon if we don’t get a deal and Jacob Rees-Mogg being his most Jacob Rees-Mogg self, the rhetoric has seldom been so charged. So we thought it’d be helpful to have all this weekend’s most alarming Brexit pronouncements all in one place. Here’s a roundup. 1. Dominic Grieve: No-deal Brexit will leave us in a 'state of emergency'  The Tory remainer told Sky News’ Sophy Ridge today: “I think no-deal would be absolutely catastrophic for this country. Clearly if the government thinks there’s a risk of no deal it’s right to take emergency measures, but we’ve got to be realistic about this, we will be in a state of emergency.” He added: “I don’t think it is scaremongering. Another way of looking at it is that it is so serious that one would hope that even if we weren’t able to reach any agreement with the EU on the economic framework we would still at the last minute put together some side-deals to address some of these issues. But you’ve got to understand that the language of some of my colleagues at Westminster is that they are actively seeking no-deal because they are so absolutely fixated on leaving the European Union without any ties or obligations at all. If that is what they want to pursue, then they themselves will be the people who precipitate this particular crisis.”  2. Dominic Raab: ‘Forgive me if I don’t keep a laser like focus on the substance’ The Tory Brexit Secretary told the BBC’s Andrew Marr this morning Brussels raising concerns about the legal position of UK citizens in the EU and EU citizens of the UK if we don't get a deal was irresponsible. He added: We ought to be trying to reassure citizens on the continent and also here. I think they’re trying to, in lots of ways…and of course neither the commission or the EU as a whole speaks with one voice. And there’s obviously an attempt to ramp up the pressure, and that’s fine. Forgive me if I don’t keep a laser like focus on the substance. He also refused to deny Britain planned to stockpile food, just in case.  Tory Remainer Anna Soubry told the : “Since the referendum, the forces of darkness have taken over and they have continued to take over and this week if there was every any doubt who was running this government it was quashed.” 4. Jacob Rees Mogg: It could take 50 years to know if Brexit has been a success  He told Channel 4: “We will know at some point, of course we will. But it’s a question of timescale. We won’t know the full economic consequences for a very long time, we really won’t.” He was challenged by Krishnan Guru Murthy, who said: “Of course not, but I mean we’ll have an indication. We’ll know if there’s been chaos, we’ll know if there have been job losses.” But Moggy insisted: “The overwhelming opportunity for Brexit is over the next 50 years.” He refused to say he’d resign if Brexit wasn’t a success, saying he puts his own future on the line at every election.  Asked if there should be a second referendum, Tory Brexiteer told the BBC’s Sunday Politics: “Absolutely not. Why do we need a second referendum? If nothing else we would need an act of Parliament to pass one. It would take at least another year or 18 months for that to happen. “But what is this, bullying? Do we say to the British people we don’t trust you in your last decision and your last vote, you’ve got to go again? Is it best of three?” 6. John Major: A second referendum would be ‘morally justified.’  Tory former prime minister Sir John Major told The Andrew Marr Show a second referendum is morally justified. He told the show: It has downsides. I mean, frankly, a second vote has democratic downsides. It has difficulties. But is it morally justified? I think it is. If you look back at the Leave campaign a great many of the promises they made were fantasy promises. We now know they are not going to be met. A referendum isn't an easy option, but it's not one at this stage that I would rule out.

title: ecuadorian president meet uk minister
story: NewsEcuadorian President to meet with UK minister Penny Mordaunt amid claims Julian Assange faces evictionThe Mirror can reveal the Ecuadorian President will meet with the International Development Secretary to discuss "a range of bilateral issues"&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter14:11, 22 JUL 2018Updated14:46, 22 JUL 2018NewsThere have been claims Ecuador is preparing to hand over Assange (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe President of Ecuador, Len&iacuten Moreno, will meet with UK government minister Penny Mordaunt in London this week, the Mirror can reveal. It comes amid claims Ecuador's embassy is preparing withdraw Julian Assange's asylum claim and hand the Wikileaks founder over to British authorities. President Moreno is in London to deliver a keynote speech at the Global Disability Summit, which is being hosted by Ms Mordaunt, the International Development Secretary. The Mirror understands the pair will meet on Tuesday, and are expected to discuss a range of bilateral issues, which could include Assange's asylum claim.  Assange has been holed up in London's Ecuadorian Embassy since 2012, when he asked the state for asylum. He was wanted in Sweden over sexual assault allegations, but claimed asylum fearing he would be extradited to the United States. He's currently wanted by British police for breaking bail conditions by failing to attend a court hearing in an attempt to resist extradition to Sweden. The Swedish sexual assault investigation was closed in 2017, but it's still possible the US Department of Justice could pursue him on espionage charges over the leaks of government documents relating to the Iraq and Afghanistan wars.

title: tory dominic raab refuses deny
story: NewsTory Dominic Raab refuses to deny Britain plans to STOCKPILE FOOD in case of no deal BrexitThe new Brexit secretary also refused to deny the M26 could be turned into a lorry park to cope with tailbacks at the border&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter10:27, 22 JUL 2018Updated10:55, 22 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNew Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab has refused to deny the Government plans to stockpile food in case we crash out of the EU without a deal. Meanwhile, senior Conservative MP Dominic Grieve said Britain would be left in a state of emergency if we do not secure a deal before Brexit day. He told Sky's Sophy Ridge: I think no-deal would be absolutely catastrophic for this country.  Clearly if the government thinks there’s a risk of no deal it’s right to take emergency measures, but we’ve got to be realistic about this, we will be in a state of emergency. He denied claims Britain would lose the right to fly over European countries and would be unable to import medicines and food were scaremongering. And he warned: you’ve got to understand that the language of some of my colleagues at Westminster is that they are actively seeking no-deal because they are so absolutely fixated on leaving the European Union without any ties or obligations at all.  If that is what they want to pursue, then they themselves will be the people who precipitate this particular crisis.  Asked if the reports of plans to stockpile food were true, he told the BBC's Andrew Marr it was unhelpful. He said: That kind of selective snippet that makes it into the media to the extent that the public pay attention to it is unhelpful. Asked again if it was true, he said: We’re making sure, both in the allocation of money, &pound3bn allocated last budget, through operational things like hiring extra border staff, through the legal arrangements both domestic, but also the treaty arrangements, we're ready for any and every eventuality. And we will gradually and responsibly, which is the right thing for the government to do, set out more of that through techical notices. He added: I’m not going to get drawn into the selective snippets that are leaked out, and hair raising stories.  He was also asked whether it was true that another part of the Government's plan for a doomsday no-deal Brexit involved turning the M26 into a ten-mile-long lorry park. He again refused to deny it. He said: Well, no, but of course. If we have no deal, we want to make sure that we’re prepared at the border for the knock on effects that would have if on the EU side they take the worst case scenario approach, which is frankly irrational. And he said Brussels raising concerns about the legal position of UK citizens in the EU and EU citizens of the UK if we don't get a deal was irresponsible.

title: tory minister suggests government acted
story: NewsTory minister suggests his OWN government acted 'incorrectly' in Brexit campaignBrexit Secretary Dominic Raab suggested the Government, in which he served as a minister, had not played fair&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter12:56, 22 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrexit Secretary Dominic Raab questioned whether his own Government's Brexit campaign was correct today, as he squirmed under questioning about Vote Leave 'cheating' in the referendum. Mr Raab was a board member of Vote Leave, who the Electoral Commission ruled this week had broken the rules by overspending during the campaign.  But he suggested there was a problem with how the Tory Government, under David Cameron , had behaved during the campaign.  Mr Raab served as minister for Civil Liberties during the period in question. Asked if he believed the watchdog was politically biased, Mr Raab said: I'm not getting into all of that - we've got the rule of law and I respect it, and there's been a report out in the papers today about whether actually the Government's campaigning was correct.  Mr Raab was referring to the Independent Commission on Referendums' report on how such polls should be regulated in future. The report does raise concerns about the potential for potentially unlimited spending of public money in favour of one side of the debate before the final four weeks of the campaign. It suggests a the ban on government communications be extended for the whole referendum period, rather than just the final month.  However, the report also calls for a full white paper on how the government is to proceed to be published before any referendum is called.  And it called for a second referendum to be triggered if the Government significantly diverges from the original plan.

title: british oil boss whose teenage
story: NewsDad relives moment son, 15, killed by speedboat propellers 'lost balance and fell in blink of an eye'Devastated Paul Finnett said he was "numb " after his "best friend and travel companion" Toby fell off the back of the boat and reportedly became caught in the propeller blades&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRachel Bishop11:00, 22 JUL 2018Updated11:39, 22 JUL 2018NewsToby Finnett, bottom left, has been hailed as an inspiration by his heartbroken dad Paul (Image: FACEBOOK)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA British oil executive whose teenage son died in a tragic speedboat accident in Greece said the 15-year-old 'lost his balance in the blink of an eye.' Paul Finnett was driving the vessel off the island of Paxos when son Toby Finnett fell off the back and reportedly became caught in the propeller blades. Mr Finnett dived into the water and dragged Toby back onto the boat before heading to the nearest port, but the boy was pronounced dead at a local hospital. A devastated Mr Finnett described his talented filmmaker son as his best friend and travel companion as he spoke about the horror of the day.  Paul, who is managing director for Aon, said: Toby lost his balance in the blink of an eye trying to get closer to his brothers, who were at the front of the boat.  He told the Mail on Sunday: We are numb – there is no pain like losing a child.  Nothing can prepare you for the shock and disbelief that this can ever happen to you. The horror incident happened last Saturday (July 14) after licensed sailor Paul hired a rigid inflatable speedboat for a day trip with Toby, his older son Benjamin, 17, and stepson Kai Stark, 14. The family were on a boy's trip when they decided to explore the nearby small island of Mogonisi, but they found themselves in turbulent waters about half a mile south of the island's port town of Gaios.  Mr Finnett paid tribute to his 'inspirational' son who he said lived life to the full in his short 15 years. Toby was a keen runner and was passionate about learning about the world, cultures and adventure and had big dreams for his future, Mr Finnett said.  On Thursday Mr Finnett changed his Facebook profile to one of Toby relaxing in the sunshine.  The family, from Littlehampton in West Sussex, are understood to live in Houston, Texas where Mr Finnett works as a managing director for the energy company. He's believed to have moved there in 1994 with his first wife, Justine Warburton, who is the mother of Toby and Benjamin.

story: NewsGoogle Maps user spots spooky 'mutant girl' walking through streetThe unnamed Reddit user decided to use the Google Street View mode in Google Maps to "walk" through the streets when he spotted two ladies, but not everything was as it seemed&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByGrace Witherden17:21, 22 JUL 2018NewsThe user zoomed in after spotting two ladies walking near a building (Image: Google Street View)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A Google Maps user noticed something very unusual when he was looking at the streets of Split in Croatia.  The unnamed Reddit user decided to use the Google Street View mode in Google Maps to walk through the streets when he spotted two ladies near a building. Wanting to get a closer look, he zoomed in and changed the angle at which he was looking at them. But it seems Google's Street View car captured a lot more than an innocent image of two holidaymakers. Bizarrely, the up-close image appears to show that one of the girls has a third leg. A third limb with toes can be seen sticking out from the sorts of the blonde girl on the right.  Users immediately dubbed the three-legged tourist mutant girl.
